content: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/ This is what a number of us knew would be coming the way of veterans when The One appointed the new VA chief. He may know little of medical services, but he sho' 'nuff knows how to screw things up worse than they were: - - - - - - - "Insulting veterans and looking like cheapskates in a time when massive government outlays to private industry would certainly help it along. Comes now retired General Eric Shinseki, who wants to save a few bucks at the Veterans Administration by making men and women injured in the service of our country pay for their care: Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki confirmed Tuesday that the Obama administration is considering a controversial plan to make veterans pay for treatment of service-related injuries with private insurance. No official proposal to create such a program has been announced publicly, [I SEE. . . THE ADMINISTRATION FLOATS ANOTHER OBAMANABLE IDEA, LIKE A YOU-KNOW-WHAT IN A PUNCH BOWL.] but veterans groups wrote a pre-emptive letter last week to President Obama voicing their opposition to the idea after hearing the plan was under consideration. The groups also cited an increase in “third-party collections” estimated in the 2010 budget proposal--something they said could be achieved only if the Veterans Administration started billing for service-related injuries. Asked about the proposal, Shinseki said it was under “consideration. A final decision hasn’t been made yet,” he said. [THEN MAKE SURE YOU DON'T MAKE SUCH A CONTEMPTIBLE DECISION, GENERAL!] Let’s see. The same administration that wants to give tens of billions of dollars to GM, Citigroup, AIG, and a host of other banks and manufacturers wants men and women injured in service to their country. - - - - - - - - - [CHANGE NO PERSON RESPECTFUL OF VETERANS WOUNDED OR INJURED IN SERVICE WANTS TO BELIEVE IN.]
reply: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/ This is what a number of us knew would be coming the way of veterans when The One appointed the new VA chief. He may know little of medical services, but he sho' 'nuff knows how to screw things up worse than they were: - - - - - - - "Insulting veterans and looking like cheapskates in a time when massive government outlays to private industry would certainly help it along. No official proposal to create such a program has been announced publicly, [I SEE. . . THE ADMINISTRATION FLOATS ANOTHER OBAMANABLE IDEA, LIKE A YOU-KNOW-WHAT IN A PUNCH BOWL.] but veterans groups wrote a pre-emptive letter last week to President Obama voicing their opposition to the idea after hearing the plan was under consideration. The groups also cited an increase in “third-party collections” estimated in the 2010 budget proposal--something they said could be achieved only if the Veterans Administration started billing for service-related injuries. Asked about the proposal, Shinseki said it was under “consideration. A final decision hasn’t been made yet,” he said. [THEN MAKE SURE YOU DON'T MAKE SUCH A CONTEMPTIBLE DECISION, GENERAL!] Let’s see. The same administration that wants to give tens of billions of dollars to GM, Citigroup, AIG, and a host of other banks and manufacturers wants men and women injured in service to their country. - - - - - - - - - [CHANGE NO PERSON RESPECTFUL OF VETERANS WOUNDED OR INJURED IN SERVICE WANTS TO BELIEVE IN.]

I hope this is nothing but rumor, if it's for real you can bet Obama is a 1 term president Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. content: quote: Originally posted by RRR52: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/ This is what a number of us knew would be coming the way of veterans when The One appointed the new VA chief. He may know little of medical services, but he sho' 'nuff knows how to screw things up worse than they were: - - - - - - - "Insulting veterans and looking like cheapskates in a time when massive government outlays to private industry would certainly help it along. Comes now retired General Eric Shinseki, who wants to save a few bucks at the Veterans Administration by making men and women injured in the service of our country pay for their care: Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki confirmed Tuesday that the Obama administration is considering a controversial plan to make veterans pay for treatment of service-related injuries with private insurance. No official proposal to create such a program has been announced publicly, [I SEE. . . THE ADMINISTRATION FLOATS ANOTHER OBAMANABLE IDEA, LIKE A YOU-KNOW-WHAT IN A PUNCH BOWL.] but veterans groups wrote a pre-emptive letter last week to President Obama voicing their opposition to the idea after hearing the plan was under consideration. The groups also cited an increase in “third-party collections” estimated in the 2010 budget proposal--something they said could be achieved only if the Veterans Administration started billing for service-related injuries. Asked about the proposal, Shinseki said it was under “consideration. A final decision hasn’t been made yet,” he said. [THEN MAKE SURE YOU DON'T MAKE SUCH A CONTEMPTIBLE DECISION, GENERAL!] Let’s see. The same administration that wants to give tens of billions of dollars to GM, Citigroup, AIG, and a host of other banks and manufacturers wants men and women injured in service to their country. - - - - - - - - - [CHANGE NO PERSON RESPECTFUL OF VETERANS WOUNDED OR INJURED IN SERVICE WANTS TO BELIEVE IN.] This practice has been going on at the VA for years. Every veteran getting care from the VA is asked if he has private insurance, medicare, or otherwise, and if he does, those are billed as required, leaving more for needy vet's. "I believe that banking institutions are more dangerous to our liberties than standing armies." - T. Jefferson

content: quote: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/ If this proposal is what it appears to be, as a 70% disabled Vet I don't have a problem with it. From what I read, the VA would recoup costs of my treatment by billing TRICARE. If that frees up funds for vets that can't afford health care insurance to be treated by the VA that's not a problem for me. If on the other hand they would charge the veteran for care, that's a whole other matter. Either way I'll hold my judgement until they actually propose something officially.
quote: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/
reply: If this proposal is what it appears to be, as a 70% disabled Vet I don't have a problem with it. From what I read, the VA would recoup costs of my treatment by billing TRICARE. If that frees up funds for vets that can't afford health care insurance to be treated by the VA that's not a problem for me. If on the other hand they would charge the veteran for care, that's a whole other matter. Either way I'll hold my judgement until they actually propose something officially.
title: Vets Treated Like Crap by Obamanation

content: quote: This practice has been going on at the VA for years. Every veteran getting care from the VA is asked if he has private insurance, medicare, or otherwise, and if he does, those are billed as required, leaving more for needy vet's. You're right Jack. And usually the first step in cancelling your primary and then having to rely on your secondary carrier. First, Aetna cancelled coverage for dependents, cut back on coverage, up the copay and the deducts. January they cancelled the policy all together citing loss of revenue sending me brochures on AARP, United Health and Part D Medicare. Several other retiree's got the same treatment from difference insurance carriers. We are now all being confined to government run programs. The amazing thing on this, they continue to cite how successful the VA programs are run and purchasing power for meds. Doesn't make sense. I don't think they really have a handle on it.
quote: This practice has been going on at the VA for years. Every veteran getting care from the VA is asked if he has private insurance, medicare, or otherwise, and if he does, those are billed as required, leaving more for needy vet's.
reply: You're right Jack. And usually the first step in cancelling your primary and then having to rely on your secondary carrier. First, Aetna cancelled coverage for dependents, cut back on coverage, up the copay and the deducts. January they cancelled the policy all together citing loss of revenue sending me brochures on AARP, United Health and Part D Medicare. Several other retiree's got the same treatment from difference insurance carriers. We are now all being confined to government run programs. The amazing thing on this, they continue to cite how successful the VA programs are run and purchasing power for meds. Doesn't make sense. I don't think they really have a handle on it.
title: Vets Treated Like Crap by Obamanation

content: I do believe this proposel is for those vets that have a service-connected disability that do not have insurance will have to find and fund that insurance. Sorta like "Concurrent Reciept" that was finally eliminated in the last couple of years for 100% disabled retirees. We had to pay from our retirement for our service-connected disability.
reply: I do believe this proposel is for those vets that have a service-connected disability that do not have insurance will have to find and fund that insurance. Sorta like "Concurrent Reciept" that was finally eliminated in the last couple of years for 100% disabled retirees. We had to pay from our retirement for our service-connected disability.

title: Vets Treated Like Crap by Obamanation

content: quote: Originally posted by RRR52: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/ This is what a number of us knew would be coming the way of veterans when The One appointed the new VA chief. He may know little of medical services, but he sho' 'nuff knows how to screw things up worse than they were: - - - - - - - "Insulting veterans and looking like cheapskates in a time when massive government outlays to private industry would certainly help it along. Comes now retired General Eric Shinseki, who wants to save a few bucks at the Veterans Administration by making men and women injured in the service of our country pay for their care: Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki confirmed Tuesday that the Obama administration is considering a controversial plan to make veterans pay for treatment of service-related injuries with private insurance. No official proposal to create such a program has been announced publicly, [I SEE. . . THE ADMINISTRATION FLOATS ANOTHER OBAMANABLE IDEA, LIKE A YOU-KNOW-WHAT IN A PUNCH BOWL.] but veterans groups wrote a pre-emptive letter last week to President Obama voicing their opposition to the idea after hearing the plan was under consideration. The groups also cited an increase in “third-party collections” estimated in the 2010 budget proposal--something they said could be achieved only if the Veterans Administration started billing for service-related injuries. Asked about the proposal, Shinseki said it was under “consideration. A final decision hasn’t been made yet,” he said. [THEN MAKE SURE YOU DON'T MAKE SUCH A CONTEMPTIBLE DECISION, GENERAL!] Let’s see. The same administration that wants to give tens of billions of dollars to GM, Citigroup, AIG, and a host of other banks and manufacturers wants men and women injured in service to their country. - - - - - - - - - [CHANGE NO PERSON RESPECTFUL OF VETERANS WOUNDED OR INJURED IN SERVICE WANTS TO BELIEVE IN.] Nothing has been officially proposed much less enacted. Now you're going to twist it to appear democrats don't support veterans. Interestingly enough, the last attack on veterans benefits was 2006. Senate Bill 3521 was proposed by then Senate Budget Committee Chairman Judd Gregg and co-sponsored by 26 other senators including the Majority Leader Bill Frist. Nothing I can find more recent than that. So which party supports veterans?
quote: Originally posted by RRR52: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/ This is what a number of us knew would be coming the way of veterans when The One appointed the new VA chief. He may know little of medical services, but he sho' 'nuff knows how to screw things up worse than they were: - - - - - - - "Insulting veterans and looking like cheapskates in a time when massive government outlays to private industry would certainly help it along. Comes now retired General Eric Shinseki, who wants to save a few bucks at the Veterans Administration by making men and women injured in the service of our country pay for their care: Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki confirmed Tuesday that the Obama administration is considering a controversial plan to make veterans pay for treatment of service-related injuries with private insurance. No official proposal to create such a program has been announced publicly, [I SEE. . . THE ADMINISTRATION FLOATS ANOTHER OBAMANABLE IDEA, LIKE A YOU-KNOW-WHAT IN A PUNCH BOWL.] but veterans groups wrote a pre-emptive letter last week to President Obama voicing their opposition to the idea after hearing the plan was under consideration. The groups also cited an increase in “third-party collections” estimated in the 2010 budget proposal--something they said could be achieved only if the Veterans Administration started billing for service-related injuries. Asked about the proposal, Shinseki said it was under “consideration. A final decision hasn’t been made yet,” he said. [THEN MAKE SURE YOU DON'T MAKE SUCH A CONTEMPTIBLE DECISION, GENERAL!] Let’s see. The same administration that wants to give tens of billions of dollars to GM, Citigroup, AIG, and a host of other banks and manufacturers wants men and women injured in service to their country. - - - - - - - - - [CHANGE NO PERSON RESPECTFUL OF VETERANS WOUNDED OR INJURED IN SERVICE WANTS TO BELIEVE IN.]
reply: Nothing has been officially proposed much less enacted. Now you're going to twist it to appear democrats don't support veterans. Interestingly enough, the last attack on veterans benefits was 2006. Senate Bill 3521 was proposed by then Senate Budget Committee Chairman Judd Gregg and co-sponsored by 26 other senators including the Majority Leader Bill Frist. Nothing I can find more recent than that. So which party supports veterans?

content: quote: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/ If this proposal is what it appears to be, as a 70% disabled Vet I don't have a problem with it. From what I read, the VA would recoup costs of my treatment by billing TRICARE. If that frees up funds for vets that can't afford health care insurance to be treated by the VA that's not a problem for me. If on the other hand they would charge the veteran for care, that's a whole other matter. Either way I'll hold my judgement until they actually propose something officially.
quote: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/
reply: If this proposal is what it appears to be, as a 70% disabled Vet I don't have a problem with it. From what I read, the VA would recoup costs of my treatment by billing TRICARE. If that frees up funds for vets that can't afford health care insurance to be treated by the VA that's not a problem for me. If on the other hand they would charge the veteran for care, that's a whole other matter. Either way I'll hold my judgement until they actually propose something officially.
title: Vets Treated Like Crap by Obamanation

content: quote: This practice has been going on at the VA for years. Every veteran getting care from the VA is asked if he has private insurance, medicare, or otherwise, and if he does, those are billed as required, leaving more for needy vet's. You're right Jack. And usually the first step in cancelling your primary and then having to rely on your secondary carrier. First, Aetna cancelled coverage for dependents, cut back on coverage, up the copay and the deducts. January they cancelled the policy all together citing loss of revenue sending me brochures on AARP, United Health and Part D Medicare. Several other retiree's got the same treatment from difference insurance carriers. We are now all being confined to government run programs. The amazing thing on this, they continue to cite how successful the VA programs are run and purchasing power for meds. Doesn't make sense. I don't think they really have a handle on it.
quote: This practice has been going on at the VA for years. Every veteran getting care from the VA is asked if he has private insurance, medicare, or otherwise, and if he does, those are billed as required, leaving more for needy vet's.
reply: You're right Jack. And usually the first step in cancelling your primary and then having to rely on your secondary carrier. First, Aetna cancelled coverage for dependents, cut back on coverage, up the copay and the deducts. January they cancelled the policy all together citing loss of revenue sending me brochures on AARP, United Health and Part D Medicare. Several other retiree's got the same treatment from difference insurance carriers. We are now all being confined to government run programs. The amazing thing on this, they continue to cite how successful the VA programs are run and purchasing power for meds. Doesn't make sense. I don't think they really have a handle on it.

content: I do believe this proposel is for those vets that have a service-connected disability that do not have insurance will have to find and fund that insurance. Sorta like "Concurrent Reciept" that was finally eliminated in the last couple of years for 100% disabled retirees. We had to pay from our retirement for our service-connected disability.
reply: I do believe this proposel is for those vets that have a service-connected disability that do not have insurance will have to find and fund that insurance. Sorta like "Concurrent Reciept" that was finally eliminated in the last couple of years for 100% disabled retirees. We had to pay from our retirement for our service-connected disability.
title: Vets Treated Like Crap by Obamanation

content: quote: Originally posted by Elesso: quote: Originally posted by RRR52: http hotair.com/archives/2009/03/12/obama-va-lets-charge-vets-for-care-on-service-related-injuries/ This is what a number of us knew would be coming the way of veterans when The One appointed the new VA chief. He may know little of medical services, but he sho' 'nuff knows how to screw things up worse than they were: - - - - - - - "Insulting veterans and looking like cheapskates in a time when massive government outlays to private industry would certainly help it along. Comes now retired General Eric Shinseki, who wants to save a few bucks at the Veterans Administration by making men and women injured in the service of our country pay for their care: Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki confirmed Tuesday that the Obama administration is considering a controversial plan to make veterans pay for treatment of service-related injuries with private insurance. No official proposal to create such a program has been announced publicly, [I SEE. . . THE ADMINISTRATION FLOATS ANOTHER OBAMANABLE IDEA, LIKE A YOU-KNOW-WHAT IN A PUNCH BOWL.] but veterans groups wrote a pre-emptive letter last week to President Obama voicing their opposition to the idea after hearing the plan was under consideration. The groups also cited an increase in “third-party collections” estimated in the 2010 budget proposal--something they said could be achieved only if the Veterans Administration started billing for service-related injuries. Asked about the proposal, Shinseki said it was under “consideration. A final decision hasn’t been made yet,” he said. [THEN MAKE SURE YOU DON'T MAKE SUCH A CONTEMPTIBLE DECISION, GENERAL!] Let’s see. The same administration that wants to give tens of billions of dollars to GM, Citigroup, AIG, and a host of other banks and manufacturers wants men and women injured in service to their country. - - - - - - - - - [CHANGE NO PERSON RESPECTFUL OF VETERANS WOUNDED OR INJURED IN SERVICE WANTS TO BELIEVE IN.] what are you all worked up for? for years the VA has asked if we have private insurance, Medicare of medicaid... VA care is expensive, and they have to be abble to make up some of the money somehow. Maybe the problem is that the VA does not treat ODS.

He may know little of medical services, but he sho' 'nuff knows how to screw things up worse than they were: - - - - - - - "Insulting veterans and looking like cheapskates in a time when massive government outlays to private industry would certainly help it along. Comes now retired General Eric Shinseki, who wants to save a few bucks at the Veterans Administration by making men and women injured in the service of our country pay for their care: Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki confirmed Tuesday that the Obama administration is considering a controversial plan to make veterans pay for treatment of service-related injuries with private insurance. No official proposal to create such a program has been announced publicly, [I SEE. . . THE ADMINISTRATION FLOATS ANOTHER OBAMANABLE IDEA, LIKE A YOU-KNOW-WHAT IN A PUNCH BOWL.] but veterans groups wrote a pre-emptive letter last week to President Obama voicing their opposition to the idea after hearing the plan was under consideration. The groups also cited an increase in “third-party collections” estimated in the 2010 budget proposal--something they said could be achieved only if the Veterans Administration started billing for service-related injuries. Asked about the proposal, Shinseki said it was under “consideration. A final decision hasn’t been made yet,” he said. [THEN MAKE SURE YOU DON'T MAKE SUCH A CONTEMPTIBLE DECISION, GENERAL!] Let’s see. The same administration that wants to give tens of billions of dollars to GM, Citigroup, AIG, and a host of other banks and manufacturers wants men and women injured in service to their country. - - - - - - - - - [CHANGE NO PERSON RESPECTFUL OF VETERANS WOUNDED OR INJURED IN SERVICE WANTS TO BELIEVE IN.] Nothing has been officially proposed much less enacted. Now you're going to twist it to appear democrats don't support veterans. Interestingly enough, the last attack on veterans benefits was 2006. Senate Bill 3521 was proposed by then Senate Budget Committee Chairman Judd Gregg and co-sponsored by 26 other senators including the Majority Leader Bill Frist. Nothing I can find more recent than that. So which party supports veterans?
